page.title: 02FEN BLOW AT FELTWELL ANCHOR
page.content: Being extremely light, the peat soil of the Fens tends to blow away in periods of dry weather. When this happens visibility can be reduced to a few yards and drifts of peat dust form in hollows and dykes, sometimes impeding drainage. This is most likely to happen in the spring when the land has not yet attained its full cover of crops. Severe damage can occur to seedlings, particularly of sugar beet, sometimes necessitating reseeding. Farmers take various steps to combat the problem. In some areas, though not at Feltwell Anchor, shelter hedges of willow shield the fields. Another method is to plant a quick growing crop such as mustard to shield young seedlings Later, selective weedkiller kills the nurse plants. It is even possible to plant rows of straw.
